contextId.information: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize diligently he studied. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: to study and to search out

contextId.information: The words "madness" and "folly" share similar meanings and refer to foolish thinking and behavior, respectively. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize how difficult the person's work is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
These two phrases mean basically the same thing and refer to every action that people do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The words "just" and "right" mean basically the same thing and refer to the kind of treatment that people deserve. AT: "fair treatment." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

Here the words "good" and "suitable" mean basically the same thing. The second intensifies the meaning of the first. AT: "what I have seen to be the best thing to do." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: what I have seen to be good and suitable

contextId.information: These two words mean basically the same thing. They refer to money and the things that a person can buy with money. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
These two words mean basically the same thing. They refer to money and the things that a person can buy with money. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the person's work may prosper, no matter what time he has done it. AT: "whether the seed that you planted in the morning or the seed that you planted in the evening." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
contextId.quote: whether morning or evening, or this or that
